docs.text: tibet has entered the american consciousness slowly during the past few years and burst into the forefront recently .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the dalai lama has made speaking tours , tibetan designs and artifacts are showing up in shops , the plight of the people has captured the imagination of major actors and artists and now there are two big budget films within as many months .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " kundun " ( " presence " , a name the monks call the young dalai lama ) opens in 1937 with the search for the 14th incarnation of the tibetan leader .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a group of monks enters a village and a two-year-old child catches their attention .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the young boy proves himself by identifying possessions of the previous holy man as " mine " .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he and his family are then moved to a monastery in lhassa where he is to be prepared to take his position as the religious and political leader of the country .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is forced into difficult decisions when china invades the country in 1950 .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the peaceful and isolated country is ill-equipped to fight off the intruders and diplomatic attempts over the next years yield no results .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: eventually he must make the painful choice to flee to neighboring india .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: comparisons to " seven years in tibet " are inevitable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: both films cover much of the same ground although the earlier movie does so from a westerner's point of view and features boxoffice draw brad pitt .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " kundun " features only native actors and is more of an insider's story .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in some ways , this makes this film a superior concept , but it lacks the movement and spark that made " seven years " such an audience-pleaser .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the actors contribute to the realistic feel of the movie ( filmed in morocco for obvious reasons ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only disappointment is chairman mao who looks like a wax dummy and moves as if he were a computer-generated character .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: on an intellectual level , it is interesting to see how two different approaches handle the same facts .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: some events are depicted differently and pitt's austrian mountain-climber who was portrayed as a pivotal influence in the dalai lama's life isn't even mentioned here .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: glossed over in " seven years " , the problems with the tibetan political system is hinted at here as the dalai lama muses " we were just about to change things " after the chinese attack .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film is magnificently beautiful thanks primarily to the cinematography of roger deakins .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his lingering camera shows the exotic tibetan culture with luscious detail .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: especially striking is an extreme moving close up of a sand mandala grain by grain .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the visual treats more than make up for the movie's faults creating a poetic meditation for the audience .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: walking out of the theater you feel like you have awakened from a transcendental experience .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: martin scorsese , known for his dark tales of the underworld ( " goodfellas " , " taxi driver " , " casino " ) has shifted gears .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: something of a thematic follow-up to his " the last temptation of christ " , this is his slowest film yet .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: oddly enough for a director with a history of graphic violence presenting a history filled with atrocities by the chinese , most of these events take place off-screen .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his decision to not over-explain rituals is commendable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the stumbling oracle who spits out his prophecies while in a trance state is much more effective as a mystery than if we were spoon-fed interpretations .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: philip glass's score is impressive although at times it is too overwhelming and distracting .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i talked to a tibetan i met outside the theater who had just seen the film and was walking back in to see it again .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: hearing his description of how he escaped from tibet at the age of seven and how his father was one of the soldiers accompanying the dalai lama during his trip to india , i was struck by what was missing in the movie .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as grand as it looks and as historically accurate as it is , there is a distance between the audience and the movie .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film is more concerned with visuals and history and less so with human beings .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: with the exception of a few scenes , involvement with the characters is slight .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: one of those exceptions is the portrayal of the young dalai lama , shown as a mischievous boy who can't resist being a kid sometimes .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: an encounter with his older brother thubten j . norbu ( a retired indiana university professor ) who tells the young leader the chinese have ordered him to persuade him to accept communist rule or kill him is an outstanding moment , but there aren't many of these .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: even with its problems , the " kundun " experience is phenomenal , but one that i fear most will miss .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: many people who saw " seven years in tibet " will have a " been there , done that " attitude .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's likely that the film will miss a wide-spread appeal and public response will be the sound of one hand clapping .
docs.label: positive
